Mozart Alves Fonseca

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/7256447451006124
  • Última atualização do currículo em 01/05/2018

Engenheiro Agrônomo (2008), Mestre em Zootecnia (2009), e Doutor em Zootecnia (2013) todos concluídos pela Universidade Federal de Viçosa. Em 2011 iniciou seu Estágio de Doutorado Sandwich no Department of Animal Sciences da Texas A & M University em Modelagem Matemática Nutricional. De 2013 à 2016 trabalhou como Postdoctoral Research Associate no mesmo departamento, conduzindo pesquisas nas áreas de Exigências Nutricionais de Bovinos de Corte, Modelagem Matemática de Fenômenos Biológicos, Modelagem de Dinâmica de Sistemas, Avaliação de Modelos, Produção de metano entérico por ruminantes e intensificação sustentável, Respirometria e Metabolismo, Formulação de Dietas de Precisão e Avaliação de Alimentos para Ruminantes com Abordagens Quantitativas de Cinética Digestiva. Atualmente é Assistant Professor no Departament of Agriculture, Nutrition & Veterinary Sciences da University of Nevada, Reno na área de Produção de Bovinos de Corte e Modelagem. (Texto informado pelo autor)

2014 - Atual
Comparative Assessment of Dried Distillers? Grain, Ionophore, Saponin, and Condensed Tannin for Methane Emission Abatement in Beef Cattle
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: A wide range of feed additives has been proposed to reduce ruminant CH4 emissions, including alternative H acceptors (fumarate, malate), halogenated CH4 analogues (bromoethanesulphonic acid, chloroform), antibiotics (mevastatin, monensin), defaunating agents (manoxol, teric), probiotics, bacteriocins, and naturally occurring plant compounds (condensed tannins, essential oils, saponins, and many other unidentified secondary metabolites. The in vitro experiment will rank the most effectives feed additives to be used within the diets in our in vivo trials. Three base diets will be formulated with increasing levels of DDG (0, 20, and 40%) to reduce CH4 production. Then the set of three diets were subset into 5 groups of three (I0, I20, I40, S0, S20, S40, GP0, GP20, GP40, CT0, CT20, CT40) and to these diets, additives most commonly used in beef cattle production systems will be separately added (ionophores, saponins, bambermycins, and condensed tannins). Diets also contained alfalfa hay, ground corn, and Bermuda grass hay. The objectives of this study are (1) to assess in vitro and in vivo the potential abatement of methane production rate of Ionophore and plant secondary compounds when fed in combination with dried distillers? grain on corn-based, growing feedlot type diets and (2) to preliminarily evaluate in vivo the blood methane technique as a proxy for methane production in the rumen. The IVGP consists of an incubator (chamber) with a multi-plate stirrer, pressure sensors attached to the incubation flasks (160-mL Wheaton bottles), an analog to digital converter device (ADC-24; Pico Technology, Eaton Socon, Cambridgeshire, UK), and a PC-compatible computer provided with appropriate software for continuous readings of the pressure every 5 min for 48 h. Each dried feed sample (200 mg) is added to an 160-mL Wheaton bottle, which contained a small Teflon-covered stir bar inside, and the bottle was filled with 14 mL of the media. Strict anaerobic technique is employed in all transfers. Blanks (n = 2 bottles), containing rumen fluid and media only, were used to adjust the gas production. All bottles are closed with previously unused, lightly greased, butyl rubber stoppers, and crimp sealed. Then, they were placed in the fermentation chamber and the respective sensor for each bottle is inserted with a needle. When the fermentation chamber reached 39°C, 4 mL of the filtered ruminal fluid was injected into the bottles. The fermentation chamber is closed and when the temperature reaches 39°C, the recording of the pressure was initiated. After 48 h of fermentation (2,880 data points per sample are collected), each Wheaton bottle was depressurized, the pH and redox potential are measured, and 40 mL of neutral detergent solution are added to each bottle to determine fiber. Bottles were crimp sealed again and cooked in an autoclave for 60 min at 105°C to determine the undegraded fiber, filtered by a gravimetric method using a Whatman 54 filter paper, and dried in an oven at 65 oC until constant weight. The 15 diets will be incubated in duplicates in the fermentation box for 6 times each, (15 x 2 x 6 x 2), and the alfalfa hay will be incubated in each run. Blanks (n = 2 bottles per incubation time), containing rumen fluid and media only, were used to adjust the CH4 production. A total of 360 bottles will be used. The CH4 (mM) is measured at the end of the incubation time by displacement using a 60-mL glycerollubricated syringe. A gas sample (0.5 mL) is removed from each bottle and analyzed for hydrogen (H2), carbon dioxide (CO2), and CH4 on a GowMac thermal conductivity series 580 gas chromatograph (Gow Mac Instrument, Bridgewater, NJ) equipped with a Porapak Q column (60°C, 20 mL/min of N2 carrier gas)..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Mestrado acadêmico: (2) Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / CARSTENS, G. E. - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Todd R. Callaway - Integrante / Tryon Wickersham - Integrante / Carlos Ramirez-Restrepo - Integrante / Robin Anderson - Integrante / Chris McSweeney - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Texas Agrilife Research - Auxílio financeiro.
2014 - Atual
Evaluation of Volatile Fatty Acids and Methane Concentrations due to Ruminal Microbe Adaptation to Continuous and Rotating Feeding Regimens of Bambermycin and Monensin, and Determination of Optimum Feeding Length of Bambermycin prior to Monensin Feeding a
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: Trial 1. The objective of this study is to assess the in vitro production of volatile fatty acids (VFA), methane (CH4), ammonia, fiber digestibility, and fractional rate of degradation of feeds using the in vitro gas production (IVGP) technique. The table below shows the composition of the diets (DM basis), using grass hay and cracked corn. Trial 2. We will evaluate the impact of different concentrations of humic acid (HA) and its combination with GainPro on VFA and methane production. Treatments will be 50, 100, and 150% of recommended levels of HA and 100 and 150% of GainPro (GP) and their combination: control, HA50, HA100, HA150, GP100, GP150, HA50GP100, HA50GP150, HA100GP50, HA100GP150, HA150GP100, and HA150GP150 (12 treatments). Data to be collected include VFA profile, CH4, fiber digestibility, and fractional rate of degradation using the IVGP technique similar to that described in Trial 1. Trial 3. There has been some experiments showing the benefits of rotating feed additives on a daily, weekly, or bi-weekly basis on ADG, DMI, and F:G(2, 4, 7, 8), but there has not been any study comparing monensin with bambermycin. In this trial, we will formulate six diets containing either monensin or bambermycin, and feed them to ruminally-cannulated steers (n = 2) at either continuous or alternating (every 7, 14, or 21 days) feeding regimens. Rumen fluid of all animals will be collected at every other week as shown in red in the table below, and a sample will be used for VFA and CH4 analysis..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (2) / Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / CARSTENS, G. E. - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Todd R. Callaway - Integrante / Whitney Williams - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Huvepharma - Auxílio financeiro.
2012 - 2013
Effect of replacing alfalfa with panicled-tick clover or Sericea lespedeza in a corn-alfalfa based dairy diet on in vitro gas production and ruminal methane production
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: Enteric methane (CH4) emissions by ruminants represent a decrease in gross-energy intake by the animal. Biologically active forage plant polyphenols, condensed tannins (CT), are known to suppress enteric CH4 production in ruminants that consume them. However, consumption of these forages alone, or in too great of quantities could result in antinutritional effects, negatively impacting ruminant efficiency and growth. Replacement of alfalfa in dairy rations with 45% of panicled-tick clover or Sericea lespedeza will suppress ruminal methane with no compromise in total gas production in vitro. Further verification of these results in in situ or in vivo animal systems is required. If proven effective, replacement of commonly fed non-condensed tannin containing legumes with condensed tannin containing legumes of similar nutritional quality, might be a viable method for improving efficiency of energy intake and decreasing the impact of animal agriculture on greenhouse gas production. The objective of our experiment was to determine the effect of replacing alfalfa with a CT containing forage of similar nutritive quality on in vitro CH4 emission. All diets contained 50% ground corn as the energy concentrate portion, whereas the forage portion (50%) of each diet was comprised of alfalfa (control) or some combination of alfalfa and Sericea lespedeza (SL) or panicled-tick clover (PTC). Our treatments consisted of PTC or SL 15, 30, and 45, which corresponded with 15%, 30% or 45% replacement of the diet (alfalfa component) with either PTC or SL..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: / Mestrado profissional: (1) / Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Harley D. Naumann - Integrante / John P. Muir - Integrante / B. D. Lambert - Integrante / SHELBY A. ARMSTRONG - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Texas Agrilife Research - Auxílio financeiro.
2012 - 2012
Assessment of feed quality for ruminants using in vitro gas production technique: building an anaerobic fermentation chamber
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: The objective of this project is to re-engineer of a fermentation chamber similar to that described by Pell and Schofield (1993) except it was designed to contain more and larger fermentation flasks. The second objective is to build a fermentation chamber in which it would be possible to record other measurements inside of the Wheaton flasks simultaneously in the future, such as methane and VFA. The sensor PX40‐15G5V (Omega Engineering Inc., Stamford, CT, 06906‐0669, http://www.omega.com) (Figure 2A) will be used. This sensor measures 0 to 15 psi (1 atm), requires an excitation of 5 V with 10 mA, and returns a voltage signal of 0.5 ± 0.11 V at 0 psi and 4.0 ± 0.11 V. During the anaerobic fermentation, there is no release of gas that is produced through fermentation and the pressure sensors report the accumulated gas. An electronic circuit was built onto a printed circuit board (PCB) to convert 12 V to 5 V. The internal resistance of the pressure sensor PX40‐15G5V, which is measured to be 3.6 kΩ. The ADC to be used to convert analog signals from the pressure sensors to a digital signal to be read by a computer will be a card with USB connectors (USB ADC‐11; PicoTech, Cambridgeshire, UK; http://www.picotech.com). This USB ADC‐11 has an input of 0 to 2.5 V. A voltage divider will be built to provide 2.5 V at the maximum output of the pressure sensor. A wood incubation chamber will be built to allow control of ideal temperature for anaerobic fermentation (about 39 oC). The source of heat will be two 100‐W lamps and two fans to homogeneously dissipate the heat inside the chamber. The 150‐ml Wheaton bottles are placed on top of plywood with the magnets located underneath. The magnets are attached to rotors that rotate so the stirrers inside the Wheaton bottles can agitate the fluid as the rotors turn the magnets..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / DE PAULA, N. F. - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Texas Agrilife Research - Auxílio financeiro.
2012 - 2012
Evaluation of Brown Midrib (BMR) Sorghum Varieties for Cropping in Central America
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: The improved dry matter digestibility of the brown midrib (BMR) sorghum cultivars is attributed to constitutive deficiencies of the lignin biosynthesis pathways which results in lower lignin concentrations. The lower lignin concentrations are expressed only in a homozygous recessive genotypes and it is phenotypically identified by a brown to tan vascular coloration present in the mid-rib of the leaf blades. Utilizing this trait increases forage consumption and productivity of both dairy and beef production. There is a need to extend this trait into more forage production systems, including those in Central America where forages constitute a major portion of the ruminants? diets. To achieve this goal, the bmr12 gene was incorporated via conventional breeding, into 16 lines derived from commonly used Central American sorghum varieties. These experimental lines were tested for agronomic performance during 2010 and 2011 in the Central American region. In addition, grain and biomass composition were estimated using near-infrared reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS) whereas the dry biomass digestibility will be evaluated using an in vitro approach as described by Tedeschi et al. (2009).The objectives of this project were to evaluate in vitro fermentation profiles of nine different Sorghum BMR varieties as a tool for cropping recommendation in Central America: Guatemala, Honduras, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Nicaragua and Panama.
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Ostillo Portillo - Integrante / Lisa Slay - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Texas Agrilife Research - Auxílio financeiro.
2012 - 2012
Comparison of fermentation kinetics of four feedstuffs using two in vitro gas production systems
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 02/03/2015.
Descrição: There is a range of possible approaches described in the literature that are used for measuring gas production. Including systems based on manual or automatic recordings in which the measures are made using mobile or fixed sensors 1993); vented or closed systems in which gas may or may not be released into pre-determined time/pressure or at each measure and wired or wireless systems in which sensors are or are not connected to computers via cables. However, to be reliable, the parameters of interest (total gas pressure and fractional pressure rate, which is used as a proxy for fractional degradation rates) need to be obtained from consistent systems and universally accepted apparatus and methods. The objective of this study are to compare two computerized systems that are used to determine the fermentation kinetics of feedstuffs fed to ruminant animals. These systems use pressure sensors to measure the pressure generated by gas released during the in vitro anaerobic incubation. Both systems are based on the in vitro gas production technique (IVGP). The systems are the wireless ANKOMRF Gas Production Systems® (aIVGP) and a wired generic in vitro anaerobic fermentation system (tIVGP). Four different samples of ground corn, alfalfa hay, dried distillers grain, and dried grass forage will be used with four replicates (n = 16). In order to preserve the same fermentation conditions, all components (sample, rumen fluid, and incubation media) will be maintained constant between the IVGP systems. After 48-h, the concentrations of hydrogen and methane in the bottle?s headspace will be collected with a syringe and analyzed using a gas chromatographer. The solution pH will be measured after the gas sample is collected and bottles unsealed and opened. The total gas production (ml/100 mg of DM), fractional production rate of gas (h-1), pH of the solution, and hydrogen and methane concentrations in the bottle?s headspace will be used to compare the systems..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Luis Orlindo Tedeschi - Coordenador / José Gilson Louzada Regadas Filho - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Ankom Technology - Cooperação.
2012 - Atual
Livestock Ruminant Model Intercomparison and Improvement
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 02/03/2015.
Descrição: The comparison of livestock ruminant models for animal performance and supply of energy and nutrients has been done for growing cattle and lactating cattle, but evaluations for nutrition excretions and greenhouse gas emission of modern livestock models are lacking. The livestock models will be investigated in North American (Cornell Net Carbohydrate and Protein System, CPM Dairy, Large Ruminant Nutrition System, and the Ruminant Nutrition System) and Europe (Wageningen and Institut de la Recherché Agronomique), and simulations will run through different diets (corn-based diets for North American scenario, grass-based diets for European scenario, grazing with concentrate supplementation, and high-grain diets for feedlot scenario) as well as two different types of ruminant animals (beef and dairy cattle, and Sheep and goats). The objectives of this study were to evaluate adequacy of 4 commonly-used livestock models in predicting animal requirements for energy and protein, diet supply of energy and protein, prediction of animal dry matter intake, prediction of animal performance, and emission of nutrients and greenhouse gas..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Mario Herrero - Integrante / Phillip Thornton - Integrante.
Financiador(es): International Livestock Research Institute - Cooperação.
2011 - 2013
Molecular weight of condensed tannins form warm-season perennial legumes and its effect on condensed tannin biological activity
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: interest in the use of native warm-season perennial legumes, as opposed to introduced species for ruminant production is increasing (Muir et al., 2005) mainly because mixed pastures offer more self-sustaining stability in the rangelands (Muir et al., 2011). However condensed tannins can accumulate to a significant level in some legumes (Wolfe et al., 2008), having anti ? nutritional effects on ruminants (Barry and Mcnabb, 1999). The plant material to be evaluated consist of leaves from native Texas herbaceous perennial legumes Leucaena retusa Benth (littleleaf leadtree), Desmanthus illinoensis (Michx.) McMill. Ex B. L. Rob. & Fernald (Illinois bundleflower), Lespedeza stuevei Nutt. (tall lespedeza), Mimosa strigillosa Torr. & A. Gray (powderpuff), Neptunia Lutea (Leavenworth) Benth (yellow puff), two ecotypes (STP5 from the Cross-Timbers of Texas and STX from south Texas) of Acacia angustissima var. hirta (Nutt.) B. L. Rob (praire acacia), Desmodium panicumatum (L.) DC. var. paniculatum (panicleleaf), Arachis glabrata Benth. (rhizoma peanut) and Lespedeza cuneata (Dum. Cours) G. Don. (sericea lespedeza). Two replications will be made by each plant species and ran in two fermentation events. The bottles inside the chamber will be duplicate as well and not considered as true replicate. Methane and total gas production will be determined using the in vitro gas production technique as described by Tedeschi et al. (2009). The bottles will be uncapped, and the pH will be measured immediately. Bottles were then will be emptied into centrifuge tubes; centrifuged (10,000 g, 4°C, 15 min) and the cell-free supernatant fluids were stored at -20°C for VFA analysis. The objectives of this study will be to determine if molecular weight of condensed tannins (CT) does not result in increased bioactivity of relative to suppression of methane production by ruminants, and to identify North American native forage plants to be used for enteric CH4 emission mitigation in domesticated ruminants. To achieve these objectives, CH4 production by fermentation of individual warm-season perennial legumes known to contain CT will be evaluated..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (2) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Harley D. Naumann - Integrante / John P. Muir - Integrante / Barry D. Lambert - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Texas Agrilife Research - Auxílio financeiro.
2011 - 2013
Determination of Production Efficiency of Santa Gertrudis Cows using a Mechanistic Nutrition Model and Integration with Post-weaning Progeny Evaluation for Genetic Merit Purposes
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: The short-term goal of this project is to identify energy efficient Santa Gertrudis cows. The long-term goal is to integrate knowledge from post-weaning trials with calves designed to examine variation in performance and feed efficiency, within-herd genetic evaluation of economically relevant traits, genomic marker data, and model-predicted energy efficiency index (EEI) of cows to develop a selection program to improve genetic merit for performance and production efficiency of Santa Gertrudis cows at the King Ranch. In order to achieve these goals accurate estimates of heritability of the EEI and the development of a practical selection criterion using EEI that a suitable for King Ranch are needed. A secondary objective of this proposal is to improve accuracy of the computer model used to predict the EEI..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / CARSTENS, G. E. - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / John Gehno - Integrante / Brandi Karisch - Integrante.
Financiador(es): King Ranch - Auxílio financeiro.
2011 - 2012
The Potential Environmental Benefit of Dried Distillers? Grain (Co)Products in the Abatement of Methane Emissions by Cattle
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: Dietary fat has long been known to affect CH4 production in the rumen by most likely acting as a defaunation agent. Dried distiller?s grain (DDG) is a feed ingredient known to be high in unsaturated fatty acids and currently available for both beef and dairy rations. For the first phase, nine diets will be formulated using Bermuda grass hay, ground corn, and alfalfa hay mixed with DDG (BPX) differing from each other based upon its DDG content (0, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 80, and 100% of diet DM). Three replicates and 4 incubation times (3, 6, 24, and 48 h) will also be investigated. For the second phase, we will use two open-circuit respiration chambers located at the Nutrition and Physiology Center, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas. The respiration chambers monitor the inflow and outflow of CO2, O2 (fuel cell oxygen, FC-1B; Sable Systems, Henderson, NV), CH4, and water vapor continuously, and all calculations are corrected for the standard temperature and pressure of the air mass flowing through the chambers (FLOWKIT 500H; Sable Systems, Henderson, Nevada). Relative humidity will be measured and used to calculate the dew point and water vapor pressure. Gas measurements will be performed using a flow-through system (RH-100). Air from each source (chambers A and B, and baseline) are sampled every 4 min. The diets will be formulated to have same level of ME (Mcal/kg) and to contain 0, 20, or 40% of DDG (DM basis). Animals will be adapted to the experimental diets for 7 d outside the chambers and then brought in for a 48-h period for consecutive gas exchange measurement. The objective of this study will be to determine the impact of different levels of DDG on the digestibility of organic matter (OM) and the production of CH4 using in vitro and in vivo experiments..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Mestrado acadêmico: (1) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / CARSTENS, G. E. - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Dulciene KArla Andrade Silva - Integrante / Todd R. Callaway - Integrante / Tryon Wickersham - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Texas Agrilife Research - Auxílio financeiro.
2011 - 2012
Comparison of Two Inocula on the In Vitro Anaerobic Fermentability of Human Waste Products
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: Human waste products have become a major environment burden to our society especially in well developed countries. Strategies to better treat the residual have long been focus of energetic power companies due to great potential that have been wasted. To investigate energetic potential of human waste products: Grass clipping, Produce, and Food scraps will be incubated for 48h using either ruminal fluid or Terrabon® inoculum with and without iodoform to determine its fermentability, gas production dynamics, and volatile fatty acids content. This work will be conducted as a 2 x 2 + 1 factorial arrangement. The bottles receiving CHI3 will be wrapped with aluminum foil to prevent UV degradation of the CHI3. Volatile fatty acids (VFA) will be determined at time zero at the end of the fermentation. The VFA will be determined in the rumen fluid at time zero and at the end of fermentations. The objective of this work is to compare the fermentability of in vitro gas production dynamics of food scraps using two inocula: rumen fluid (control) and Terrabon® inoculum with and without iodoform (CHI3 = triiodomethane)..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Cesar Granda - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Terrabon Inc. Renewable Energy Solutions - Auxílio financeiro.
2011 - 2012
A feed evaluation system to predict the biological value of corn milling co-products and their combinations
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Luis Orlindo Tedeschi em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: To initiate the project, 120 co-product samples will be obtained from facilities producing ethanol co-products. Time table for sample collection will be short. Tentatively collection period will beginning in December 2010 and will occur twice weekly. Because one of the project objectives is to improve the ability to predict and account for the nutrient variability, methods must seek to identify and include samples of variable nutrient content. More specifically, many outlying cases will be of special interest because they deviate from our currently accepted dogma surrounding current predictive models of nutrient content and availability. Identification and examination of these cases may provide important clues as to how current predictive models should be modified to improve precision. In addition, these peculiar outlying cases may also lead to the finding of other model inadequacies, such as the omission of important variables. The fermentation dynamics in the rumen will be measured using a computerized gas production system (Pell and Schofield, 1993, Tedeschi et al. 2009). In this system, small amounts of ground sample is incubated inside 125 ml Wheaton serum bottles in a temperature-controlled chamber and gas pressure is measured every minute for 48 h. Then, the degradation rate of NDF is obtained from the convergence of nonlinear functions of the gas pressure data. The objectives with this project is to refine the new methodology on soluble protein disappearance adjusted for microbial protein using in vitro anaerobic fermentation..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Mozart Alves Fonseca - Integrante / Tedeschi, L.O. - Coordenador / Paul J. Kononoff - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Poet Nutrition - Dakota Gold Research Association - Auxílio financeiro.

Desempenho e exigências nutricionais de animais F1 Angus X Nelore inteiros e castrados
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Sebastiao de Campos Valadares Filho em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: Avaliar diferenças em consumo, desempenho, eficiência e características de carcaça de bovinos F1 Angus x Nelore inteiros e castrados abatidos com diferentes pesos; Determinar as exigências nutricionais de proteína, energia e macrominerais para bovinos F1 Angus x Nelore inteiros e castrados abatidos com diferentes pesos; avaliar a predição da composição corporal a partir da composição química da seção HH (Hankins & Howe) para bovinos F1 Angus x Nelore inteiros e castrados; avaliar as digestibilidades e parâmetros ruminais, bem como produção microbiana de bovinos F1 Angus x Nelore inteiros e castrados abatidos com diferentes pesos; avaliar os modelos de exigências nutricionais de zebuínos propostos no BR-CORTE (2010) utilizando banco de dados independente; avaliar o uso de diferentes modelos matemáticos na descrição do crescimento e determinação da maturidade fisiológica de bovinos F1 Angus x Nelore inteiros e castrados; Estimar a inter‐relação entre medidas biométricas corporais e composição da carcaça; desenvolver modelos matemáticos a partir de medidas biométricas que possam ser utilizadas para predizer a composição corporal de bovinos F1 Angus x Nelore inteiros e castrados..

2009 - 2011
Exigências nutricionais de vacas Nelore em lactação e de seus bezerros, do nascimento à desmama
Projeto certificado pelo(a) coordenador(a) Sebastiao de Campos Valadares Filho em 25/02/2015.
Descrição: O projeto de pesquisa proposto será conduzido no Departamento de Zootecnia da Universidade Federal de Viçosa, objetivando‐se determinar as exigências nutricionais (energia, proteína e macrominerais) de vacas de corte em lactação; determinar as exigências nutricionais (energia, proteína, macrominerais e aminoácidos) de bezerros de corte em crescimento, na fase de pré-desmama (0 a 6 meses); determinar a eficiência de utilização da energia metabolizável para ganho de peso de bezerros de corte em crescimento na fase de pré‐desmama..
